title: Write Logs to Persistent Disk In Addition to Stdout
body: As part of our production monitoring efforts, having logs persisted to disk would be massively helpful as we will not be reliant on cluster nodes being alive for monitoring certain behavior.
See: https://github.com/sirupsen/logrus/issues/689
I'd like to work on this one.

To clarify the requirements, we need to support flags to specify where to log to file as well as the format. 

Example flags:
```
--log-file=/path/to/file.log
--log-file-format=json
```

We've done similar format selection in #2594

questions regarding the requirements :
1. Which file formats do we need to support?
2. Do we need to support splitting the log files by size or date ("rolling log file") ? it would make sense to do that and prevent a situation where there one huge log file.

At a minimum, we want to support the same formats we log to stdout. 

Rolling logs, maybe if it's not complex but it's not a requirement
Got it.

Hi katzdan, if you have some extra time would it be possible to also add a --log-verbose flag? It would be handy to be able to read console output as normal, but have full logs saved to file.

I can add the right methods to the library to be able to log to stdout and to a persistent disk, perhaps allow the user to specify the filetype as well.

Learn more [on the Gitcoin Issue Details page](https://gitcoin.co/issue/prysmaticlabs/prysm/2395/2990).


**2) [katzdan](https://gitcoin.co/profile/katzdan) has been approved to start work.**

Already checked if logrus lib supports multi-writer mode (yes, it does) and what it doesn't (file rotation and different log level for linked writer). 
next phase : implementing this feature on a sample project.
final phase : implementing in the project itself along with the test code for the argument that triggers writing the log to file.

Learn more [on the Gitcoin Issue Details page](https://gitcoin.co/issue/prysmaticlabs/prysm/2395/2990).

I've analyzed the code and it has almost 2k lines that use `log` package. Most of usages `log.Print{f,ln}` without any custom logger. 

You can somehow change them all using find/replace, @katzdan but that would produce huge codebase update, since logs are used everywhere. It is hard to test this change as logging isn't unit tested, as I understand. 

This is Go, guys, wouldn't it be better to find out some other state-of-the-art solution like redirecting `stderr`/`stdout` output into disk/network stream (which could be later replaced with logging to remote LogServers for backup or whatever) through use injection into `log.Print{f,ln}` currently used?

Your thoughts, @prestonvanloon ?

@gutsal-arsen - 
According to what I saw in the source code - in the Beacon Chain and Validator the logs are written with logrus lib (github.com/sirupsen/logrus). 
This lib supports multiple writers in a very straightforward way which @prestonvanloon pointed out.

In regard to usage of logrus  - 
1. There is not builtin support for file rotation.
2. There is no simply way to have two different log level for stdout and file logging if a MultiWriter is used (you have to use different logger instances) so @uto-pia  - It looks like the output for stdout and file would look the same (at least for now).

@katzdan that's more architectural idea, not implementational. I saw the budget, tried to figure out how much time is needed to simply find/replace and tried to measure risks. And I'm not a Go guy, so know nothing about `log` and `logrus` implementation. Just tried to find out the way to simplify at this phase, then probably suggest next phase which would cover logging with unit testing and finish the unification  job safely.

@gutsal-arsen you must be mistaken. Only these packages import `log`
```
tools/faucet/server.go:8
tools/bootnode-query/main.go:11
tools/ssz-server/main.go:13
contracts/deposit-contract/depositContract_test.go:8
contracts/deposit-contract/drainContracts/drainContracts.go:8
k8s/geth/prober/main.go:8
shared/ssz/hash_cache_test.go:5
```

We often alias `logrus` logger to `log` so if you are just greping for "log" then this is not correct.

This suggestion is the best so far: https://github.com/sirupsen/logrus/issues/689#issuecomment-357042506

```go
mw := io.MultiWriter(os.Stdout, logFile)
logrus.SetOutput(mw)
```

The remaining unknown is how to specify different log to file vs stdout logs. We would like for users to have the nice TTY stdout while having JSON logging. This is likely a very small change on the order of 10 to 20 lines of code and does not required detailed unit testing.

if the requirement is for the output to have the same log level msgs with the same format to both stdout and file then the `MultiWriter` option is indeed the best and simplest. 
Alternatively -  if we are to support different log levels (as per @uto-pia 's request) or different formatting for stdout and file I don't see how this can be done with `MultiWriter` and we'll have to use hooks or some other means of triggering of the file logger whenever logs are written to stdout.
@prestonvanloon -  please advise how to proceed.
thanks

Json logs would definitely be more helpful to me than verbose logs, if it's one or the other... I'm more interested in Json logs for the validator and verbose logs for the beacon chain. If you can't add the verbose logs it's no problem (nobody likes them but me), I could use some kind of pseudo-terminal to pull info from the verbose log instead of vice versa

from further review of how logrus lib works - hooks will only get triggered for the specified log level and up so if the stdout logger is configured to log INFO and up - there is now way to get DEBUG/VERBOSE logs to be written, so @uto-pia - the --log-verbose flag would affect both stdout and file logger (if that OK with everyone else).

Due to complication in log output format that we encountered - writing logs to file will currently only be supported in the same format output to stdout. This means that you cannot have text format in stdout and json written to logs. Sorry @uto-pia , hopefully this will be amended in the future.
